IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Promote the long-term availability of affordable housing to low-income persons.
IRS990.MissionDesc: To improve the environment for efficient and substantial non-profit initiatives which promote the long-term availability of affordable housing for low-income persons by, but not limited to (1) improving operations and enhancing the production capacity of nonprofit developers; (2) raising funds and developing equity to support housing initiatives; and (3) education of non-profit developers and the public.
IRS990.Desc: HDC provides collaborative settings and opportunities for nonprofit developers and others to increase affordable housing. HDC works closely with government, environmental advocates and community coalitions to raise the awareness of the broad benefits of affordable housing and to implement sound public policies that lead to increases in the quantity and quality of such housing throughout King County. Recent accomplishments include: HDC's Policy/Advocacy team successfully worked to fund affordable homes by helping to pass King County Affordable Housing Bonds legislation, secured increased allocations to the ARCH Housing Trust Fund, helped secure a $75 million Washington Housing Trust Fund investment, negotiated historic equitable development investments as part of Sound Transit 3, and adoption of a new local funding option for affordable housing capital, operations, maintenance, as well as mental health facilities and services.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: HDC Membership is available to organizations who share our commitment to the development and preservation of low and moderate-income housing to meet affordable housing needs throughout King County. HDC delivers value to our members by collective advocacy on policy, resource and regulatory issues; providing policy expertise, technical assistance and data resources; member education and engagement through topical, cutting edge programming; assistance and facilitation in advocacy agenda setting; affinity groups that provide opportunities to share knowledge and best practices, develop policy proposals and exchange ideas; regular electronic communications and networking opportunities; recognition of members among peers, elected officials and the general public of accomplishments and leadership in the community.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: HDC undertook a review of the Leadership Development Program (LDP), and relaunched it as the Leadership Development Initiative which expanded upon the introduction to leadership provided in the 'survey course' to offer more advanced and in-depth training and career development opportunities for HDC members, including housing development finance, asset management and human resources. The 2015 cohort of our Leadership Development Survey Course (LDSC) graduated 18 future leaders in affordable housing. LDSC is designed for staff of HDC member organizations who demonstrate commitment to the field, leadership potential, and who will benefit from gaining further insight into what it means to be a leader. In addition to a structured learning environment, opportunities are provided for self-exploration, for building relationships with others and for growing networks with experienced leaders in the affordable housing sector. The Program serves as an introduction to the many and varied roles of leaders in mission and values driven organizations.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HDC is exempt from federal income tax as an organization described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and is not a private foundation within the meaning of Section 509(a) because it is an organization described in Sections 509(a)(1) and 170(b)(1)(A)(vi). As a result, there is no provision for federal income taxes in these financial statements and no federal income taxes were paid. Management believes that the Organization has adequately addressed all relevant tax positions and there are no unrecorded tax liabilities. Federal and state tax authorities generally have the right to examine and audit the previous three years of tax returns filed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Any organization, whether non-profit or for-profit, public, or private for-profit or private nonprofit, is eligible to be a member of the Corporation if it demonstrates its commitment to and abides by the goals, principles, purposes and protocols of the Corporation, as established by the Board and the membership from time to time.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The HDC Board of Directors may recommend and the membership has the subsequent right to elect members to the Board during the organization's tax year in the case of resignations or if the Board is below its 21-member maximum roster.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The HDC membership, acting through member representatives, has the right to approve or ratify decisions of the HDC Board, such as approval of the governing body's recommendation's for election or removal of members of the Board, or approval of the Board's decision to dissolve the organization.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HDC's Board Finance Committee reviews the draft 990 with the Executive Director, requests clarification and adjustments if warranted, shares drafts with entire Board and makes recommendation to full Board for acceptance.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Upon or before hire, election or appointment, each employee and Board member must provide a full written disclosure of all direct or indirect financial interests that could potentially result in a conflict of interest. Examples include employer, business and other nonprofit affiliations, and those of family members or a significant other. This written disclosure will be kept on file and will be updated annually and as needed. Should there be any dispute as to whether a conflict of interest exists: the Executive Director shall determine whether a conflict of interest exists for an employee, and shall determine the appropriate response; the Board of Directors shall determine whether a conflict of interest exists for the Executive Director or a member of the Board, and shall determine the appropriate response.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Executive Director - Comparison to similar roles and responsibilities and wage levels as documented by United Way of King County is done annually - most recently 2015.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Upon request members of the public may request and are given access to governing documents, policies and financial statements
